text:
Or I guess based on this from the manual
```Package directories provide a simpler kind of environment without the ability to handle name collisions. In a package directory, the set of top-level packages is the set of subdirectories that "look like" packages. A package X is exists in a package directory if the directory contains one of the following "entry point" files:

X.jl
X/src/X.jl
X.jl/src/X.jl```
I really just want to know "how do you make a package directory"?

X/src/X.jl

attachments.title: Scripting like a Julian
attachments.text: I’ve been talking to a few people and since this topic comes up regularly, I thought I’d write up my workflow for writing “scripts”. I don’t have a standard blog or place to put this, so I thought I’d put it here and tag it as guide. If this is misplaced or inappropriate, please tell so that I can move it to some other, more permanent place. What you’ll need Texteditor of your choice Revise.jl That’s it! Background Scripting is usually done in a haphazard manner, just throwing things in a fil...

text: Very fair question. It is quite likely my workflow here is not recommended, and I would love to learn a better workflow. But basically I have some local code which I want to organize into modules. It's all scripty, not a formal _package_ that's a git repo with `src/` and `test/` . Just files `A.jl` which defines `A`, `B.jl` which defines `B`, etc. I want to be able to use this code interactively by pulling up a REPL and `using A`, `using B`, etc.

If you want to put your packages on GitHub or similar, I recommend PkgTemplates.jl

text: Weird quirk of Julia is that the "packages fit to be published to the world" workflow is actually much easier than the "mucking about locally" workflow. <https://github.com/evanfields/TravelingSalesmanHeuristics.jl>

elements.text: Weird quirk of Julia is that the "packages fit to be published to the world" workflow is actually much easier than the "mucking about locally" workflow.

text: having things organised in projects with a Project.toml and Environment.toml also helps heaps for dependency management
